root.pub-comments: This tree is an amalgamation of subtrees of the pidgin and creole trees provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.
root.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: A creole with predominantly Spanish vocabulary and Philippine-type grammatical structure.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Malaysian Creole Portuguese, Malaccan, Papia Kristang, Kristang, Portuguese Patois, Serani, Bahasa Serani, Bahasa Geragau, Malaqueiro, Malaquense, Malaquês, Malaquenho, Português de Malaca, Malayo-Portuguese
child.geography: Malaysia (Peninsular), Trankera and Hilir, Melaka, Straits of Malacca. Related varieties in parts of Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. Variety in Pulau Tikus spoken more in 1997 than in 1987. Also spoken in Singapore.

child.pub-comments: Spanish relexification. Historical relationship with Chavacano and dialects, which are still spoken in the Philippines. The Jakarta variety of creole Portuguese survived in Tugu until recent times (1981 Wurm and Hattori). Varieties of creole Portuguese were also spoken in Larantuka, Flores; Adonara (Vure), Solor; as well as Sumatra, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, and Maluku. Varieties of creole Portuguese were also spoken in Banda and Ambon.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Maluku), north Maluku, Ternate Island, west of Halmahera Island. Varieties of Portuguese creole were also spoken in Banda and Ambon.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: New Caledonia, southern, Ploum, Mont-Dore, and especially Saint Louis, near Noumea, and Paita.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: It is based in Indonesian and Javanese. It has Mandarin elements in contrast to Baba Malay, which has Hokkien elements. Developed at the beginning of the 17th century among Low Malay-speaking Chinese traders from Fukien who married Javanese women.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Java and Bali), east and central Java.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: The descendant of a pidginized form of Standard German which originated in the Gazelle Peninsula of New Britain during German colonial times among the Catholic mixed-race ('Vunapope') community. With increased mobility and intermarriage, it has been disappearing in the last few decades.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Papua New Guinea, East New Britain Province, Rabaul. Also spoken in Australia.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Unlike Tok Pisin (Papua New Guinea) and Pijin (Solomon Islands) there are some French loanwords. Partially intelligible with Pijin and Tok Pisin.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Vanuatu, also spoken in New Caledonia.

child.pub-comments: Although not named by the author, it is noted that: There are dialect differences between lowlands, highlands, and the islands. The highlands lexicon has more English influence (J. Holm).
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Pisin, Pidgin, Neomelanesian, New Guinea Pidgin English, Melanesian English

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Papua New Guinea, lowlands

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Papua New Guinea, islands

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Papua New Guinea, higlands.
Papua New Guinea, mainly in the northern half of the country, and now well established in Port Moresby, and into other regions.

child.pub-comments: Basic vocabulary is closer to standard English than is Tok Pisin of Papua New Guinea. Grammar shows Melanesian features. Pronunciation varies according to local languages. Historically related to Tok Pisin of Papua New Guinea and Bislama of Vanuatu. Intelligibility of Bislama is quite high. Creolization in progress.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Solomon Islands

child.pub-comments: A creolized language from the Sapuahfik dialect of Ponapean and English whose genesis is the direct result of a massacre in 1837 of adult males on Ngatik by British traders.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Micronesia, Ngatik (Sapuahfik) Atoll, Ponape, east of the Caroline Islands.

child.pub-comments: The basilect (heavy creole) is barely intelligible with Standard English (H. McKaughan and M. Forman 1982). There is a continuum of speech from the distinct creole to Standard English of Hawaii.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, all the Hawaiian Islands, USA mainland (especially the west coast, Las Vegas, and Orlando).

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Closest to North Moluccan Malay. Also close to Sri Lankan Malay. Influences from Portuguese and Ternate. An important, growing lingua franca in many parts of Sulawesi.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Sulawesi), North Sulawesi, Minahasa District, west coast around the port of Manado. Used as second language by many in North Sulawesi.

child.pub-comments: Loanwords from Rote, Portuguese, Chinese, Uab Meto (Atoni), Sabu, Spanish, Dutch, English. Author lists that there are two dilects, but only names one.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Indonesia (Nusa Tenggara), Kupang and surrounding towns, West Timor.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Maluku), Banda Islands..

child.pub-comments: Marginal intelligibility of Indonesian. Difficult intelligibility of Ternate Malay; speakers switch to Indonesian. Lexical similarity 81% with Standard Malay. Developed from Bazaar Malay and still reflects some archaic forms. Further diverged by adapting to the vernaculars of central Maluku. Considered to be a Malay-based creole by B. D. Grimes (1988, 1991) and J. Holm (1989:581–583).
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Indonesia (Maluku), Central Maluku, Ambon, Haruku, Nusa Laut, Saparua Islands, along the coastal areas of Seram, and southern Maluku. Also spoken in Netherlands, USA.

child.pub-comments: 'A Malay-based creole which is quite distinct from both standard Indonesian and from other Malay-based pidgins and creoles'. It evolved by the mid-19th century. Unique phonological, morphological, and lexical traits. There are also influences from Peranakan Chinese and Bali. Often not intelligible to Indonesian speakers not familiar with it (R. B. Allen, Jr. 1989).
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Jakarta Malay, Betawi Malay, Batavi, Batawi, Melayu Jakarte
child.geography: Indonesia (Java and Bali), Jakarta, Java.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: There are important differences with Tetun in parts of the grammar, morphology, functors, and much of the lexicon. There is heavy influence of Portuguese and some Indonesian or Malay loans in Tetun Dili. There are 3 second-language varieties spoken by different people: (1) fluent Tetun Dili spoken throughout the western part of East Timor, primarily by those who have lived in Dili for one or more years, (2) occasional Dili residents with significant influence from their own first languages, and (3) people originally from East Timor who are overseas residents in Portugal or Australia, with higher portion of inflected Portuguese vocabulary and almost complete lack of Indonesian or Malay loans. There is also 'Tetum Ibadat' or 'liturgical Tetum' which is not spoken by anyone for everyday communication, nor as first language, with a lot of vocabulary and some grammar that is not understood widely. Speakers of North and South Tetun have significant difficulty understanding it in many speech domains, and vice versa. Heavy Portuguese and Mambae influence. Compared to Tetun: many more Portuguese loanwords.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Tetun, Tetum, Tetum Prasa, Tetum Praça, Dili Tetum, Tetum Dili
child.geography: East Timor, First-language speakers concentrated in and around Dili on the north coast of East Timor. Second-language speakers scattered widely throughout the western part of East Timor.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Influences from Dutch, Javanese, and Betawi. Little is known of this language. May be a pidgin or mixed language, rather than a creole.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Java and Bali), Djakarta (Batavia), Java

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Linguistically a pidginization of True Motu. Also influenced by English, Tok Pisin, and Polynesian languages. Speakers of Hiri Motu cannot understand Motu. There are phonological and grammatical differences. Lexical similarity 90% with Motu.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Papua New Guinea, Central Province, in and around Port Moresby area, also throughout Oro, Central, Gulf, and part of Milne Bay provinces, some in Western Province.
Oceania
